Character 8/10-The characters aren't that bad well they have different personalities that whats makesthe anime really interesting for me.Character progression was very interesing it was fast but atleast there bonds to each other get stronger right?\n\n
Enjoyment 8.0/10 - It was fun all in all to watch this anime.If u are interested on an anime with good animation funny moments and RPG gaming this anime is right for you :)\n\n

Story: The plot has a good proposition about approaching the lives of people excluded from society who find in electronic games an outlet for their frustrations and together they interact to become better and better adapted human beings to the society that previously seemed extremely hostile to them. There was a great margin for the development of the characters, but this expectation did not materialize, either because of bad script choices, or because the original material was very large and this development would occur later. I think it should be the role of the director to be able to pick up elements of the story'smost advanced points in order to give a worthy conclusion to a short anime like that. So watching this anime is frustrating in many ways, with so many episodes being spent for literally no development.\n
Art: the design is OK. the choice of mouth design really annoyed me. I've never seen a mouth with only the lower lip. Really strange. The animation was not very smooth.\n
Sound: very generic. \n
character: probably the best item of the work is the conception of the characters. So watching Netoge becomes even more frustrating, since the development of these characters is very small. 12 episodes may not seem like much, but I've seen lots of animes doing a lot better than that with the same amount. My biggest frustration is with the development of the couple Rusian and Ako. The staff could have given an original ending in which she begins to better understand the difference between reality and games, and understands that Nishimura and Rusian are different persona, and that she wishes to be with Nishimura. This could occur in the episode where Nishimura has his character hacked, and Ako starts to question herself what would it be of her relationship with Nishimura, now that Rusian is gone. But the director missed the opportunity to do an original development starting from that point. A satisfying ending would be Ako and Nishimura beginning to date like real people in the real world, with a kiss to give it a good ending. But the element of romance seems to have been cast aside in terms of the development of the plot, and has become only a comic element for the show. And this was unforgivable. \n
Enjoyment: At the beginning I enjoyed it. From episode 8 onwards it was just disappointment and frustration. The staff has chosen as a climax point a in game event, vaguely related to a real life event, that is the cultural festival. The climax point should be a real life event. It would give much more meaning to it. \n
Overall I don't recommend this anime to anyone, unless it is a person desperate for a anime to watch, and have watched every anime I have watched that i think it's better than this one. This is a classic exemple of anime that it would be better if it had not followed the original material (LN)

There's nothing inherently *wrong* with [Excessively Long Anime Title Anime]. If you're into game-type series with a lot of physics-defying high school grills then I expect you'll get value from the twelve episodes. So, worth watching? Not really. It was never bad enough for me to drop it, but the last three episodes had me watching on half the screen while researching grilling tips for my Grillmaster™ 5000™ and sorting my extensive collection of Grill™ Images™ on the other.
It's not really a harem anime because there's only one grill in the running, but the other collection of QTs stick around the boring protagonist like gumon the bottom of a school desk put there by some random Stacy while she blew Chad Penninghampgoldworthton and then forgotten about just like her prescription for Zovirax. There's nothing special about any of the main or side characters, although that doesn't mean they lack charm or personality. It's obviously nothing you haven't seen before, but they're still fun to watch. Also, the animation is top-quality and some of the panoramas really are beautiful.


What really salts my dripping axe wound is the premise/co-main component of [ELATA]: the video game Legendary Age. At first I somewhat enjoyed the game world because it allowed an alternate storytelling path for the characters to grow--even though I really, super-duper don't like vidya animes. Then it just kept going to the point where the last couple episodes are all about the game. This sucks because by that point in the series I didn't give a dry turd about the game, I wanted to watch the characters interact IRL. I'd "gotten to know them" and wanted that to take priority over an endless stream of MMO cliches. And speaking of, some of the memes spouted in dialogue are overused (normie scum) bordering on cringey.


But like I said before, there's nothing *bad* here, but it's definitely not good either. I didn't hate my time because I did finish it, but I also can't really recommend it either unless you're really into the vidya anime "genre."

tl;dr: An MMO focused romcom that is quite original despite being yet another MMO anime due to being more grounded, realistic, and focused.
This anime had a good amount more depth than I expected in a lot of areas. First off, rather than the game being based on anything too extravagant, it's based on a simple sprite based MMO, but that actually worked really well. It went into issues with MMOs that are more realistic than the large-scale futuristic stories you find in most VRMMO anime, such as dealing with protecting your password and dealing with admins, so that was surprisingly interesting. Thought the way the anime was portrayed,with things happening in the game being portrayed as if they were real life, felt kind off as a lot of things simply don't make sense as being possible in that format. They should have at least done a 3D game with voice chat instead of sprites with text boxes I think, though I do understand that that would require changes to some plot lines. What was just as if not more interesting as the MMO aspect, was Rusian and Ako's relationship. It was interesting in that it wasn't based on developing a relationship exactly, in that they're already married in a way, but rather moving their relationship from the game world to reality. Hence, it was centered more around them having different understands of what they're relationship was and synchronizing that, rather than than love itself blooming between them, because it's essentially maxed out from the beginning. Hence, the relationship and character development that occurs is Ako coming to accept that the real world is different from the game world, but isn't completely pointless and worth living in, but also Rusian coming to accept that real life and games aren't completely separate and that things to a certain extent things like relationships certainly do carry over. So they're moving towards a center from two opposite sides. Now, this development is ultimately really small, baby steps really, but its fleshed out and was really enjoyable to watch happening. Furthermore, Ako's character is really adorable, with her voice acor being really good and fitting, and her chemistry with Nishimura is amazing, so they're just an incredibly enjoyable couple to watch in general. Akane and Kyou had potential but felt like they were in serious need of being fleshed out more, as they were rarely if ever the focus at all. The comedy and the laid-back, light-hearted mood were also really appreciated. \n\n
The art and animation were solid. The character designs were pretty great. The OP/ED were also really good, and the show made good use of rolling the ED while things were still happening on screen. The soundtrack wasn't particularly memorable outside of the use of the instrumental versions of the OP/ED.

My advice for Netoge? Judge it by the cover.
Don't expect to pick up this series and receive a well thought out plot, characters with insane depth, or any really heartfelt romance. It's the type of anime that can easily parade itself around as if it has all of that, but it only has all of it in certain moderation. If you watch Netoge, you shouldn't be expecting something that would be able to claim a place as a keystone anime, but something that, as long as you appreciate the genres, will not be 'bad'.
Before you read any type of summary or reviews, you'll probably buildsome interest by the images you see. There's no shame in that, because the art for this anime is beautiful. The colors are bright and happy, the lighting they use in various scenes is done very well, and overall it's just so smooth. Cardboard-Cutout-MC-kun is one thing, but the girls are so cute, you really have to try hard to not want to watch it.


On the subject of cute girls, Ako is absolutely adorabley cringey, Master is the lady neckbeard we all want to see, and Segawa is our tsun (-dere is being looked into). Master, or Kyou if you must have a different name, is great. The 'premium gamer' everyone wants to be, but everyone hates to see. She pulls it off in a fashion that doesn't get annoying, but still plays the 'rich kid' trope that's needed for harems. On the other hand, we have Segawa, filling the spot for the classmate and tsundere. Fortunately, this isn't an anime that really gives a love triangle, or square, or really anything you'd expect from the usual harem. Segawa doesn't ever give off the appearance of having a legitimate affection for Nishimura and honestly, it's the one thing I couldn't have hoped for more.  She gives off her tsundere tones, but is able to play nice, and doesn't interfere with the romance we were given.


Now, turning attention to the two that are most important, Nishimura and Ako. Ako is great in a lot of senses of the word. She's cute, both in looks and the way she acts, she's cringey, but adorable at the same time. The problem with her is that she doesn't have friends and spends so much time in her room, but it's shown so much that its to no fault of anybody but herself. She's awkward, quiet, and basically tries her hardest to not be involved with anyone at school. Seeing a little of that mentality shaved away over the course of the season was great, but there was a lack of enjoyment for me seeing this gorgeous girl so against 'normies'. As for Nishimura, his reactions weren't the greatest. He'd react to Ako's affection, react to any typical anime mishaps, but all of his reactions were just kind of sub-par. I hoped for a little more, but he was ultimately pretty dull throughout the series.


As far as the story goes, I pretty much gave my opinion on it at the start of the review. If you want a romance, harem, or otherwise, there are better options for the genre you want found elsewhere. Netoge does all of the things it says it does, but on a lesser scale. However, while that sounds bad, it leaves a lot of room for the characters to just kind of be themselves. The interactions you get from them just sitting in a room together are enjoyable because rather than being a setup for something bigger, it's just idle banter.


I would definitely recommend it if you want something nice to watch, but again, I do feel that if you're on mission to watch a specific genre, there are better options. Don't expect too much from a series that is wholeheartedly just enjoyable.

I love video games! I am a huge gamer and I totally love playing video games. You can clearly say from my user name that I am a gamer. So I have to like this anime right? WRONG! This anime was disappointing and I could not stand it at all! (Note: This is a first impression, because I just could not watch the whole series for how boring it was, but you can go and read other reviews if you want a proper one.)
For this review I will be focusing on story, Art style, characters and my overall enjoyment.
Story: The story of this entire showis absolutely ridiculous. A bunch of gamers that play an mmorpg together and for some reason one of the girl can't distinguish between the gaming and real world. Honestly there are thousands of anime about mmorpg, so this one is not anything new. I mean seriously, it will take more than four weeks for me to count how many there are. Basically this anime is a remake of a million other anime and they tried to put their own little twist in it because otherwise it will be copyright. In conclusion the story isn't anything unique, moving on.


Art: The art style is my favorite, the main reason I got into anime is mainly because of it's art. A lot of people might disagree with me, but hey everyone is entitled to their own opinion. The art for "Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta?"

feels refreshing to see, the colors are great and the characters look super cute. Although this type of art isn't anything new, I still like it.


Characters: The characters are the tropes that you would find in your average harem anime. You have the tsundere, the shy girl who is also some what of a yandere. You can find all those tropes in here. The protagonist also doesn't play any super big role either. I wouldn't remember any of these characters because they are all technically a bunch of other characters. 


Enjoyment: I did not enjoy this at all, I was bored to death! This show is VERY disappointing and boring, they don't have too much to show off but harem girls in cute clothing that just so happen to be gamers.

Pros: The art is pretty good and the music is alright
Cons: Literally everything else
I actually felt like throwing up while watching this anime, it was that bad. I don't know how I did it. How I pushed myself to get past the first episode and finish the series. I swear that if I didn't take a break every four minutes I wouldn't have made it. And so, here we are. I've fought my way through and made it here, only to be met with positive reviews and a decent MAL score. What was I expecting, I wonder. To anyone who enjoyed this anime, hats offto you, I'm glad that you thoroughly enjoyed yourself, I really am. Thanks for reading, take my review with a grain of salt and have a good day.

Perhaps the most endearing part of this anime was that it was relatable and rather honest and it didn't rely parlor tricks or on making all of the characters clueless and excessively violent for its comedy, sure it had a little bit of that, but it wasn't excessive to the point of being mundane. Also there was this hilarious yandere element which I've never seen in a comedy anime before this and i was totally anticipating Ako Tamaki to start killing people which added a great element of tension which was resolved as they developed her character further. Also for being an ecchi anime themain male protagonist wasn't an obnoxious pervert nor was it focused on being overly pandering. it was just over all well balanced.


To rate it: the story was average, the art was nice, the sound was decent, the characters were well done and it was over all really enjoyable.


I've watched several romantic comedies that were total garbage being neither funny nor even developing the romance and this anime delivered on its promises. Its not an exquisite story but it was entertaining. This was a light hearted ecchi romantic comedy game anime and while there are a plethora of this genre this was a good example of how to do comedy right and i was giggling all the way through. Could have gone for more diversity in the bust size department as they only offered extra large and extra small but honestly this anime was pretty great. Also Akane Segawa / Schwein is my waifu!

Once again, I was just looking for something nice to kill some time, and "Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta?" or NetoYome sounded quite interesting.
And said in short, I was not disappointed with that one.
The synopsis sounds simple: Teenager confesses ingame to his beloved cat-girl-character, but she refuses him because she is actually an older "he".
How could he have seen THAT coming...?
Now he strictly separates online from offline, and the series starts with our MC being part of the guild "Alley cats", consisting of 4 players.
Did not sound like a probably awful SAO clone, but like some fun and playing with MMORPGtropes.


The story offers no great surprises and dramatic plot twists, you can guess the outline of the plot quite well just by looking at the title pic, perhaps with one little exception.

But nevertheless, it is still fun to watch.

Although there are many girls involved, it is not a harem show, and I think that fits quite well for NetoYome.

The romance part does not feature deep crisis and other dramatic events that are often found in romance series, but instead shows the transition of a relationship from online to offline, with both characters being far from normal, and their transition.

As for the comedy part, it made me laugh a lot, it featured a lot of different tropes, often presented in an unusual way.


Art is well done and enjoyable, except some minor CGI parts.

Game graphics is presented in 2 ways, rather simple, blocky and pixel-ish when shown on a monitor, and realistic, often switching back and forth.

There are lots of panty and boob shots, and the mandatory beach and bathing scenes are present as well.

Censorship is minimal, some strands of hair or a little foam over the most important parts, but no annoying beams of light or massive amounts of vapor over half of the screen.


Sound was decent and enjoyable, VA fitted quite well.


Characters are put together from different tropes mostly, but in a funny and somewhat believable way, not just annoying standard.

They all have some kind of development, not forced but feeling quite natural.

Details in the spoiler section below.


As I said before, I liked NetoYome a lot, grinned and laughed a lot.

The humour, self-awareness, irony, tropes abuse and uniqueness is what makes a comedy show stick in my head for longer.

Boobs and ecchi stuff are fine, I don't deny that, but if that is all a show has to offer, I will forget about it quite soon.

But there were also some things that made me think a little, like the hikikomori hints (see below).


*** The following section contains spoilers! ***

*** If you do not want to be spoilered, please stop here. ***


The male lead is Hideki or "Rusian" (I think this is some misspelled form of "Lucien", "Lucian" or some sort of it, at least it often sounds like that).

Because he confessed online to a girl character who turned out to be a man, he strictly separates ingame and offline.

Now he is finally married ingame with the female character Ako, after she confessed to him multiple times.

They have chatted a lot, and he likes her character very much.

But he doesn't care who/what that character is offline, at least at first, the only important thing to him is that she is a cute character, as some kind of self-protection.

He is a gamer and kind of an otaku, but still has some offline friends.

When they all meet, Ako treats him as his husband because of their online marriage, but for him, they are two different persons.

It takes him some time to realize that Ako is Ako, be it online or offline, and to overcome his rejection from earlier.


Ako, the female lead, is a very reclusive girl with no offline social skills, she often skips class and has built up a wall around herself, but she seems satisfied with that.

At her first appearance in the show, she collided with Hideki, hung her head and ran away.

Online, she is also clumsy and stuff, but Rusian was always kind to her, and supported her, so she began to like and even love him.

For her, online is somehow more real than offline, and she does not separate both at all.

She is married with Rusian online, so when they meet offline, she calls him and sees in him her husband, which leads to obvious problems.

She loves Rusian, be it online or offline, that is no difference for her, no matter how desperate her friends from the guild want to explain that difference to her.

Hideki confesses to Ako multiple times, but she always refuses him.

Not because she doesn't like him, but because they are already married from her point of view, so that would be a downgrade of their relationship.

During the show, she grows in self-confidence, a small step for a normal person, but a giant leap for her.


Akane is a classmate of Hideki, she seems absolutely normal and does not want to have anything to do with otaku or gaming culture.

She acts like a typical tsundere, although Hideki comments he misses the dere part.

As we get to know soon, she is a secret gamer, and is a member of the same guild as Rusian, although she plays a male character named Schwein (which is German for pig, and she doesn't know that meaning, it just sounded cool for her).

When the guild has its first offline meeting, she is shocked that anyone could find out about her playing online games, and that her days as a normal student could be over.

At first, she acts as if she didn't know Hideki or Ako, but Ako doesn't care about that and even calls her by her online name.

Later on, she opens up to the others offline as well, and kind of overcomes her fear from being seen as not normal.

Her online character changes from male to female after is was revealed that she is a girl, at the first occasions only some short flashes, but then permanently.

We get some quite subtle hints that she might have feelings for Hideki, but she never makes direct any moves towards him, only the way she acts sometimes and a Freudian slip.


Kyou is the student council president.

Her parents are very wealthy, but she doesn't brag with it, they own just some companies and schools (one of them being the school they all attend) and stuff, it is just normal for her.

She had never had any friends, maybe because of her family's wealth and her kind of untouchable aura, but she was never happy with that.

As it turns out, she is the leader of the guild, and she also plays a male character, which changes to female later on.

Because of her wealth, she owns tons of expensive special game items, and doesn't care at all how much they cost.

After the offline meeting, she got real friends for the first time in her life, which makes her complete domestic staff cry for joy when she invites them to her home.

She even installs a computer game club at their school, so she along with her new friends and guild members have a club to go, and to teach Ako the difference between online and offline.

For her, we also get some very subtle hints that she might have feelings for Hideki, when she asks him to call her by her first name, she completely blushes, and when she slightly blushes whe she wants to oil up Hideki with suntan, but she doesn't make the slightest move either.


Ms. Saitou, a young teacher at their school, is a strict but very caring person who understands her students very well.

She is happy that Ako has made some friends, and is concerned when she skips class to lock herself in.

Later in the show, it is revealed that it was in fact her, to whom Hideki once made his confession, she just couldn't tell him that she was a teacher, and she didn't know that she was his teacher.

Her online character is cat-like with ears and a tail, she often ends her sentences with nya (meow) and exposes a very childish behaviour, just like a teenager.


Before the guild meets offline for the first time, Hideki thinks his guild consists of 3 males and a female or perhaps just 4 males, but now he is suddenly surrounded with 3 pretty girls from his very school instead, one of them claiming to be his wife.

Reality flipped upside down, who would have seen THAT coming?

Ok, you could have guessed it from the title pic, just like I did, killjoy...


During the show, we get an interesting view of how an individual becomes a NEET hikikomori.

Ako is socially (self-)isolated, fears the offline world and immediately runs away from any danger or uncomfortable situation.

She skips class and is well prepared to lock herself into her room for a week at any time, she even has a refrigerator in her room.

She even thinks of dropping school completely, to have more time for her online game, where she feels safe and comfortable.

Although presented in a comedy manner, it made me at least think a little...


Comedic highlights: When Hideki comes to Ako's home trying to convince her to continue school, he unlocks the door and sees her in her underwear halfway on.

He is embarrassed, immediately closes the door and tells her to get herself ready, but when he opens it again, she sits there completely naked and asks him to be gentle...

I like it when tropes are mashed up!


You can't have an ecchi show without the mandatory bikini presentation and suntan-rubbing scene, but this one here is different.

When Akane and Kyou arrive at the beach, they are disappointed that Ako is already there, because they wanted to show their bikinis at the same time to Hideki, to get him a nose bleed.

After that, he gets oiled up by all three girls simultaneously, and feels quite abused.


Or the typical bathing intruder scene: Hideki is sitting alone in the men's bath, when suddenly the door opens, and he jumps up. 

Ako, wrapped in a towel, wants to bathe with him, and now sees him standing in the basin, completely naked.

When she is pulled away by her friend, she refuses loudly and wants to stay.

Did I already say that I like it, when typical tropes are put through the grinder and flipped completely upside down?

*This is my first review so it may be bad, sorry. Also, apologies for any spelling/grammar mistakes*
Netoge is one of those shows where it can be tough to get through an episode, it's repetitive, slightly obnoxious, and sometimes boring.
Story (5):
I gave the story a five since it can be pretty unclear at times, the genre is comedy, NOT romance. A romance anime usually revolves around a couple and their development (although, obviously, there are some exceptions). This anime tries to be romance but overall fails. It's about Rusian and Ako's 'relationship' and also the rest of the club trying to get Ako to realize thedifference between the real and fictional world. Even though there are only 12 episodes, the story seems to me like it gets so dragged out, Ako's character just becomes annoying and ridiculous. At the time of me writing this review (10 episodes seen), she just annoys me and I honestly don't think the story will have a complete and good conclusion.


Art (7):

The art in this show is actually very enjoyable. I really like bright and colorful anime and it really goes with the feeling of the show. At times, the fanservice can be ridiculous *cough* the sun lotion scene, but at times the fanservice can be suttle (kind of...). There's not much to say about the art, it goes well with the show but it isn't anything too special.


Sound (6):

The sound in this show is above average. The opening can get tiring after a few episodes and in my opinion, I even found it annoying. Then again, there we're times I would find myself humming it or getting it stuck in my head. The background music is kind of generic and the sound effects are pretty good, again, there's nothing too special about the sound.


Character (3):

Oh boy, this was the part I was excited to write about, I just love bashing on horrible things.


Rusian is pretty bland. He is a good main character that most can relate to, he plays a video game and meets a girl who was actually a 'boy' and falls in love with her, she then admits that she is actually a 'boy' in real life, making Rusian 'heartbroken'. His flaws are that he has a delusional wife, he meets her in real life and actually falls for her. That's about all I can think of, he's a pretty average person in game and in real life.


Ako is, hands down, the WORST character in this show. At first, I thought she was pretty cute albeit a little annoying. As the show progressed, it became apparent that she couldn't differentiate the real world and the game world, she just thought life was one big game, or they were the same thing. The rest of the club tries to help her realize that they are two separate things, but she flat out doesn't listen. At first, I thought that was a pretty good flaw, but towards the end of the anime, she showed no signs of improvement. As you probably noticed, it gets very annoying and repetitive. Rusian wants them to be a thing, but Ako just won't listen because she thinks they're married. Onto some good things about Ako, there are very little. At times, she can be funny, but she's really just whiny, possessive, and childish.


Akane is a girl for all the loli fans out there. She is stuck up, but also 'cute' her character is overall, okay. She is bratty and doesn't want to be seen around any of the other club members in school. She does have a caring side for them though, and considers them very close friends of hers. To sum her character up in one word, tsundere, that's pretty much all she is. Sometimes she can be pretty goofy though, those moments kind of save her character.


Kyoh is the calm and collected character, she is usually the one in charge and keeps everyone from slacking off. Like Akane, she is pretty okay overall, she also has her silly moments as well. Sadly, her character is mostly just there for fanservice.


Nanako is very annoying, she comes in later in the show and is also just for fanservice. She is rarely with the rest of the club and has just a very annoying personality, she's also very bland and just follows Akane around like a lost dog.


Yui is the teacher and also the club supervisor. She's not really annoying like most of the cast, but she can be pretty bland. She is basically just the glue that holds the club together, they need a teacher in order to have the club and that's her, she also has a pretty useless character in game. Whenever the rest of the cast needs help though, she usually steps in with her "Neko-hime protection squad".


Enjoyment (5):

When I first started this anime I enjoyed it, towards the end it just annoyed me. Some of the jokes are really funny and relatable to people with basic gaming knowledge, other times, they can be pretty bad and cringy. Ako was the big problem with me, but the story and events in the episodes just became obnoxious and hard to watch at times.


Overall(5):

I wouldn't recommend this anime to someone who's looking for a romance anime.


I wouldn't recommend this to someone looking for a comedy anime.


I might recommend this to someone who is looking for a fanservicey anime.


I might recommend this to someone looking for a gaming anime.

A hardcore gamer finds allies within a game and it turns out they all go to his school. They form a club and have fun times toghether. Pretty much the gist of the anime. Nothing crazy or orginial but i really enjoyed it. It has a lot of funny moments in it and a lot of dudes love hot gamer girls(I know I do). The cast is your standard cast. There's the harem captain aka lead male Nishimura. He's a hardcore gamer who is considerate and kind and has the most common sense. He has problems with male gamers using female characters. Then there's themain girl Tamaki. She's a delusional gamer girl who escapes from reality and falls for Nishimura in the game. She's a busty airhead and has no common sense at all. She is adorable though. It's like a busty girl with a little girl mind. Speak slowly and make sure to relate everything to a game like ''man that final exam was a high level boss''.  And she might be borderline perverted towards Nishimura. Now the side cast, Segawa and Goshouin. Segawa is a twin tailed blond loli tsundere. Yeah I know. Theres millions of chracters like her. Lol. She acts like she hates Otaku but she's a big one. She just wants to fit in and be a ''normal'' girl. Please they're boring, those normies. Be you Segawa-chan, i dont judge. Lastly Goshouin. She's a rich busty student council president. She screams ''out of your league'' but she's nerdy. She can out class you that way too. With her 10 monitor freakin top line gaming setup. Us mere peasants fall short. I aint worried though, im a short haired loli lovin man myself. Lol. Thats all.

Maybe you will think this anime is good because it's about people playing videogames. But let me tell that you are wrong.
The two main characters are terrible, a silly girl who always thinks about videogames but actually she is so bad at it and the typical protagonist who likes the girl, who knows why.
Sometimes you will enjoy this anime, but the female main character will destroy the good moments because of her personality. 
Also there are videogame concepts that are wrong.

Oh boy, were in for a ride.The wet dream of every weeaboo and Fedora-wearer:A Girl who plays videogames, looks like a model and is mindlessly in love with the MC.WHAT COULD GO WRONG? EVERYTHING.
Do you know that feeling when you watch people being really, really stupid on the Television? I feel the same while watching this mess of a show.You could also compare it with a cringe compilation.So, what even happens in this wish-fullfillment fantasy?
Dont let yourself be fooled by the description on MAL, the element that MC proposed to some girl on the internet before is thrown out of the window in one ofthe earlier episodes to fit in more ridiculous "video-game talk".Its basically just a really uninteresting and needlessly stretched romance, and like digibro said in his review for this "There is no reason why they should not fuck immediately".


The art is bright and flashy.I have no clue about anime art , but im just gonna say that it was the only reason why i didn't try to pour something really hot into my eyes.


The soundtrack is completely bland and i cant remember any melody, except for the opening because it is so painfull.


The Characters are either full-on trope embodiments or go halfway through with the stereotypes.I dont know which is worse to be honest , but the main girl is kind-of a yandere, so if thats your cup of tea you might want to...no.Dont.Watch Mirai Nikki instead, at least they tried there.(I have not watched Mirai Nikki but im a hundred percent sure its better than this)


I enjoyed the first half of the show because of the reason mentioned earlier: its like watching very stupid people do very stupid things and laughing at them.The characters behave so unnaturally stupid and clichee-like, its hard not to laugh.After a short time it became just boring , so maybe give it a try when you are drunk or on other substances.


I apologize for any spelling mistakes, its 1 AM and im bored and annoyed at the same time, because this show gets 10-point reviews.Ew!

Look, before I say it, this anime is never going to win awards for being innovative or epic like other animes, but it has something about it that makes it feel special. However, I feel like they didn't capture that essence of the anime enough and that's why I can't rate it an 8 like I so wanted to.
The Story:
So, get this. The story is about a group of highschoolers playing video games. No, not getting trapped inside video games or being transported to a fantasy world that has the rules of an RPG. They are sitting around, playing video games. There is more tothe story than this, but let me just say how refreshing it was to watch character who actually enjoyed playing the game itself and their interactions with the game and other people in the game instead of some life or death scenario while being trapped in a video game or something (shots fired ;))


Now, I did say their is more to the story than just what I said before. One of the characters, Ako, turns out to have the distinct inability to distinguish her roleplaying character from herself, and thus she fails to separate the real world and video game. It is the job for the other characters to help her understand this difference. They do this through making a club at their school (yes, all he members of their guild happen to be at the school it's plot convenience roll with it).


Art:

Okay, sure it's not the most amazing art out there, but IMO it in't completely trash. The art style has such a playful style to it that was pleasant to watch. It was a very cute style, it works, and they change in style from the real world to the game world was great. I feel like this is a good place to mention it, but I do appreciate that they show each person's in game character in universe rather than just their images on a screen, although it might give some people the wrong idea.


Sound:

Nothing unique, but it had an OST that very well complimented the anime's lighthearted feel but also accentuates the dramatic moments of the show.


Characters:

I'm glad that they characters aren't generic harem archetypes like they appeared to be at the very start of the show. Instead, we get video game archetypes, which I am perfectly okay with. Nishimura and Akane are both casual players who know enough about the game to get by, although Akane does roleplay "her bad self". Master (I can't remember her real name) is a premium player, and it's beautiful to see that even it anime, everyone hates premium players. Sette (real name forgotten) is the complete newbie who doesn't quite get how the game works. And then we have Ako, who I've mentioned before.


What this show really does is show the slow real life friendship of Akane and Nishimura, given that Akane was the "closet Otaku" who played but never admitted it while Nishimura was open about it. Watching the two of them become friends, and I MEAN FRIENDS, not harem material, was great. The other was Ako's slow development in understanding the rules of real life that differentiate from the game's world, and you can see it.


Now, for what i enjoyed about the anime. I've mentioned before that the fact that it was an SoL about the group playing games. The other thing are those moments when they ave humor that pokes fun at other ecchi tropes, specifically the beach episode trope and the undressed girl behind a door things, both of which they play up and then make the BEST jokes out of. Honestly, the second arc is hte best for me.


However, there did become a point, specifically in the 3rd arc before it got to more of a climax where they seemed to be focusing randomly on the busts of the female characters (except Akane, cause she's flat and you can't have that in a fanservice shot). This started to irk me because they seemed ot just randomly ramp it up as if the second arc hadn't gone about poking fun at other tropes.


Anyway, this series isn't for everyone. I don't personally know who I'd recommend it to and I've seen so many people get triggered by the amount they cringed at the show, which is understandable because there are some dumb moments. However, I personally enjoyed it despite its stupidity, and I'm sure there are other people out there would would feel the same.

Gather round, scrubs. It's another anime about video games.
Normally when you get a video game anime, it's handled pretty poorly, just look at Sword Art Online. Unfortunately, the same applies here. This show's main flaw is that it tries to achieve too little, effectively being a standard highschool rom-com. Which is a shame, because it seems to understand its audience pretty well and the inner workings of a video game. It's sad to see that such knowledge not to its full potential.
Now that that's out of the way, i'll just sum up the rest of this quickly.
Story- 5/10: 
Cut/paste occasionally lewd high school romance withlittle to no closure at the end. \n\n
Art- 7/10:\n
The art can be pretty nice, out of everything, the thing that stands out most is the commercial cut stills which is a photography still with Ako placed somewhere. As for the rest of it, it's decent quality.\n\n
Sound- 6/10:\n
Nothing notable or memorable.It mainly just served it's purpose without being stand-out. Voice acting is about all I can compliment\n\n
Characters- 6/10:\n
The characters are not very unique and you've definitely seen them in some shape or form in other shows. Some might say Ako, but if we're being honest, she's just gonna be a Doujin printing machine for the coming months like Hotaru from Dagashi Kashi. \n\n
Aside from that, unless you have broad taste in anime and also enjoy video games, I can't recommend this show. You'd be better off watching something else.

Thoroughly disappointing. the main heroine was a total poster-girl, mainly existing just to be shown off with (simply annoying) fan service. The story lacked any sort of depth, the jokes fell completely flat and the art style varied in quality.  Typical mmo type anime which are currently flooding the business.
While the season did have an ending of sorts, it didn't really solve the issue that was presented in the anime, that being Ako's social problems. Especially the last few minutes were a complete joke, pissed me off and made me lower the score even more. 
I wanted to keep watching to see where theshow was going, some parts were a bit more serious but then they just went on to the next 'funny' scene ruining the atmosphere.

And you thought there is never a girl online?...well errr...well duh of course there's girls online!.
Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta? is once again is a anime genre with an " MMO game elements" just under a meta-magnifying glass and oddly enough it works.
Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta? is like trying to change someone's view on reality to the online MMO world and simultaneously be a pseudo-harem at the same time and LA at first thought that this concept was done to death (characters in a game-sense anyways) however Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta?made even this work to an extent to the point LA got invested in the main cast.


In terms of characters, have a rather diverse and eccentric cast and heck even a main male protagonist that isn't such a dense idiot. LA's favourite character is the "waifu" of this anime being Ako Tamaki voiced by Rina Hidaka and her pseudo-yandere/shy tendencies warmed up to LA quite quickly, sure there are some quirky other main cast members, such as the "Schwien" tsundere Akane Segawa voiced by Inori Minase and the premium item buying president of the student council and the guild master of the main cast Kyou Goshouin voiced by M.A.O. What the best character development actually goes to is Ako and the main protagonist' Hideki "Rusian" Nishimura's relationship in both reality and in the game and greatly helped making this anime what it was, what's better is that Rusian ISN'T a dense main male protagonist and that is rather refreshing, what's rather weird and unique is Ako's take on her "gaming and real" relationship to Rusian and sure there are some melodrama here and there from both of them but we get to see their relationship develop (as well as a detriment) throughout the anime. 


Many of the meta narrative takes place with the MMO the cast plays and the "gameplay elements" makes some of the plot the others is through atypical harem tropes (just to make sure, this anime isn't quite a harem anime, it's a pseudo one, Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta? is more of a romance anime with a gaming tag and a psuedo-harem element to it), anyways Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta? reminds LA playing LA's first MMO and some of the trials and tribulations LA got into talking to the society of the MMO LA played (If you really want to know, it was Elsword, sure it's the not the same classic MMO game but LA gained knowledge about MMO terms from Elsword, sue LA that it isn't similar to Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta?'s Legendary Age...LA...huh...no comment).


In terms of animation by Project No.9, yes this anime has lots of "animation facial derps" here and again, but Project No.9 had a certain charm to it mainly through the MMO animation elements to it and because of that the animation was actually decent enough LA could give some grace to the animation derps here and there, character design wise, they have distinct appearances and a sort of bloom to them which only brings out the main cast's personalities even more.


As for voice acting, LA just thinks that Rina Hidaka who voices the main heroine, Ako Tamaki had a blast in voicing her, the other voice actors also had something like this too, but seriously it felt like that Rina Hidaka had so much fun voicing Ako.


Ending-wise, they made something mundane made awesome in some respects and does give Ako a bit more of a personality accepting some of school life using MMO to do so. Romantic-wise, -sigh- sooo close...soo close. Overall, the ending was decent enough for LA to give the "romance" side some grace.


Netoge no Yome wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta? is by far for LA was a surprise of Spring 2016, it's not only from it's meta-narrative to it's characters but the certain charm of being somewhat relatable to LA's MMO gamer side and one eccentric pseudo-yandere.

Story: 6/10
I like the story because it creates some really funny scenarios.
Art: 7/10
The art was really good. It stayed consistent and I liked the costume designs of the characters when they were in the game. It was just the right amount of brightness. The only problem I had with the art is that all of the girls had the same lips in which they had lipstick on their lower lip. Honestly, it's not that big a deal because they are still cute.
Sound: 9/10
The music in this anime is surprisingly good. I liked the opening and ending songs and the music they played during the actionscenes were better than I thought it was going to be.\n
Character: 9/10\n
I love all of the characters. They each have their own personalities and traits that make them stand out. Also, I felt a connection between all of them in which I believed that they were actually friends and worked well together. I do wish that we got more backstory on them like how they became so obsessed with net games.\n

I really enjoyed it. Every episode was hilarious and I liked the action scenes too, especially in the last episode.\n

This anime was surprisingly good. Good comedy. Although one of the genres for this anime is ecchi, it's more fanservice than "shove it in your face" ecchi. Definitely recommend it.\n\n

There's a common misconception/joke in the gaming community, which goes by the fact that "Girl gamers do not exist."  And while yes, the idea of girl gamers is a goddamn myth, anime brings us the unique perspective on what life would be like if there were girl gamers.  And so we are presented Netoge, a show all about one boy's shock to finding out that they indeed exist, and the dangers of crippling gaming addiction. 
Story: Nishimura Hideki is your average everyday gaming otaku who spends a lot of time playing the show's MMORPG known as 'Legendary Age'.  After getting his heartbroken after finding out that his previous in-game love interest was actually a guy playing a female character (cause that TOTALLY doesn't happen IRL), he swears to himself that he would never again fall in love with another in-game character ever again.  Fast forward two years, and he's married to someone in-game (great dedication there, buddy).  Even more so, he finds out that his in-game wife, Ako, is actually a person from his school, and is actually a real girl!  Not only that, but he also finds out that Ako has a crippling problem of discerning reality with the in-game world, as she constantly refers to him as 'her husband' and calls him by his avatar's name despite the two of them not...really knowing each other all that well.


The main plot of Netoge is mostly about trying to get Ako to reenter back into reality through various means.  Either by trying to show her how good the real world is, have her do some things without a computer, or just socialize with people her age, the main plotline follows Hideki, or Rusian (since hell, that's what everyone in the show calls him) and the rest of the members in their small guild try and condition Ako back to being a normal girl rather than being the somewhat incompetent healer that she plays in-game.  All the while we follow the actual real-life romance of a boy trying to cope with a girl that he most likely will be taking care of and marrying for the rest of his life in the future.  In addition, with its main draw on online game, most predominantly MMORPGs, Netoge also capsulizes on different tricks and situations within a game of that genre by spending a good chunk of its runtime doing things in-game, visualizing situations, and showing the characters actually playing the game that the show is wrapped around to give us a bit more than doing an intervention for a 17 year old girl.


Another plus for the series comes in its usage of ecchi.  Now, not saying that fanservice is good, but the amount and the way that Netoge does it is certainly much more tasteful and enjoyable than just plastering boobs on a screen.  Most of it is done in a more comical sense and doesn't use your generic 'dude landing on the girl's boobs' or 'walk in on the girl naked' so as a result, I don't find the ecchi all the jarring or takes away from the series in any way.


The show however does have one fatal flaw with it, and that comes in the way of its actual focus on plot.  Towards the middle of the series, the show shifts to focus more on other aspects on the series rather than its core focus on trying to reintroduce Ako back into society.  As such, the series loses its way a bit and diverges down the different path of focusing solely on game-related content to the point that I myself even forgot about on what the point of the series was until the very end and then I remembered 'Oh right, this show was about helping a girl with her addiction.'


Overall though, Netoge showed itself to be a very peculiar show that wasn't as gritty or deep as other shows are when it comes to dealing with hikkiomori-like characters (Like NHK) and provided a light-hearted and happier example all the while showing its audience other parts of its story, such as its romance, which while it didn't particularly go anywhere special (because thanks for that troll ending, Netoge), was still rather cute to go through and watch.


Overview:

+ Lighthearted story that delved into hikkomori lifestyles

+ Other plot aspects aside from the main story

+/-  Some ecchi (if you're not a fan of ecchi, any ecchi, tread carefully)

-  Other aspects invaded and took over the show in the latter half

-  Bit of a troll ending 


Characters: As expected with a show involving hardcore gamers, the characters of the show are all members of an extremely small guild of four members where each of them pertain to a certain role in a battle party.


First there's Nishimura Hideki, or Rusian, the main protagonist of our story.  Rusian is a boy that embraces his in-game life and his experiences online yet doesn't entirely reject the idea of real life.  Rusian as a character doesn't really stand out in the way of an interesting character.  He likes playing net games, sure, but he doesn't have any particular interesting character traits aside from masterfully being able to manage Ako and have an iron will of patience when dealing with her and her lovesick demeanor.  That being said, he does grow in the series and devotes his screentime to helping his guild as the party's tank, as well as helping his in-game wife, being not a lowly pervert or overpowered protagonist, but just your average gamer who doesn't spend money on a game who just wants to have fun.  


Then there's the real reason why the series exists, Tamaki Ako, Rusian's wife in-game, and potential wife IRL.  (Cause there is no reason given how the series was going that these two were not going to get together.)  As mentioned before, Ako confuses the idea of reality and game to the point that to her, the two are basically the same thing, hence why she's confused over why her friends and her 'husband' make such distinctions.  Similar to Rusian, she doesn't really have many characteristics beyond being addicted to online games and has her heart set on being a housewife.  She does grow as the series goes along as well, which does give the series a sense of progress, albeit not as big due to the changes from beginning to end not being quite severe.


Finally, we have the two remaining members of the guild, Akane and Kyou, or the fighter and the mage of the group.  These two characters play the normal person trying to hide her online gaming tendencies and the whale who spends money for cash items in-game.  These two characters play more as a supporting characters in the main cast, as their role in the series is to aid our main couple more than anything else.  Like their other guild members, they don't particularly have many interesting traits about them due to the characters pretty much being one-note and the plot is largely story-based, but they do have more merit to them than the actual supporting cast.


The supporting cast is largely filled with mooks and other really unimportant or one-off characters that only appear once or twice in the series.  Aside from Nekohime and Akane's friend (whose name escapes me), everyone else is pretty much nonexistent in terms of actual character importance.


Overview:

+ Character growth

+ Focused character importance

-  Most characters are one-note

-  Side cast is essentially worthless and/or non-existent


Art: Produced by Project No.9, the studio who created...Saikin no Imouto and...Kouya...(I think I threw up in my mouth a bit), the art for Netoge is a very light, almost shiny color scheme that radiates brightness and relates back to the happy and lightheartedness that is the series's tone.  As such, the colors of the show are almost muted with white and shine and are very high light in that regard.


The character designs of the show are moe.  Not even gonna sugarcoat it, the look of all of these characters are just straight up cute girl designs.  The quality of animation for them is very consistent despite No.9 being a company that hasn't had much of a track record but due to the very common cute girl trope that the show goes for a lot of the time, this aspect of the show may drive some people away.


As mentioned before, the show does have ecchi.  And very clearly due to the fact that the majority of the female cast each have quite a sizable bosom.  There is one character design that just screams 'female armor' but aside from that, the actual fanservicey scenes are few and far between, and are never just blatant boobs on the screen all the time.  Maybe a few movements here and there when the girls are doing some dramatic action, but that's about it in terms of consistent fanservice in the series.


Overview:

+ Good, consistent animation

+/- Fanservice (Though not as much as you may think)

+/- Moe artstyle (Dependent on your view of moe)


Sound: The soundtrack for Netoge really...isn't all that special.  There's nothing that really stands out aside from them being a pair of really cutesy OP and ED combo that expresses the main romance of the series between Hideki and Ako (or Rusian and Ako to be more exact).  They're not really special, they're not unique, so they're as a result not really very memorable.


Personal Enjoyment: I was following the manga before the anime's release and thoroughly enjoyed it.  Due to scans slowing down, the anime caught up and went far beyond the original source material, so there really isn't enough to make a comparison one way or the other.  What I can say is that despite its flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed this series.  I'm one of those suckers for a good OTP, and despite the show sorta...pasting them together, the Ako x Rusian ship was pretty cute.


Did I enjoy this anime?


Yes, I did.  As a gamer, I recognized/understood pretty much all of what the show was showing us and really enjoyed the different aspects overall.  Ako is such a wonderfully weird character that really breathed life into this show due to how much was actually focused onto her, and the show really didn't let go of anything that it had plot-wise throughout its whole run.  (Although it may have had a tough time balancing everything all at once though.)


What didn't I like about this anime?


Really though, it's the ending that kills the show for me.  I'm not gonna spoil what happens, but many romance anime do it, and it is just not fun to watch anytime they do it.


Would I recommend this series?


If you're looking for a fun and not so serious game-related anime, then Netoge is worth a shot.  It's a largely story-based anime that concentrates on its aspects of romance, reconditioning, and games throughout its entire runtime, while adding some slight fanservice that doesn't really take too much away from the show, mixing it altogether with character development that is actually pretty noticeable as the episodes roll by.  The characters aren't all too deep or complex, but it has some merit to it and in my opinion, is an all-around decent show.

Classic anime revolving around otaku and online MMOs. The story is very clear and easy to understand. There is a main plot in this anime, which is to get the female main to understand that the reality and in-game worlds are separated. However, this plot is not very well developed as it isn't focused on, even though it is the main plot. Despite this, there are many many other sub-plots which were very interesting to watch.
This anime includes multiple female roles. However, this is not a harem anime! The male main shares his love with only one female. That being said, their relationship is abit weird but also interesting because of the fact the female main cannot or has difficulty seperating the in game world and reality.


The art of this anime is pretty modern, and very well animated. Similar to SAO. However, the effects could be worked on a little more.


Overall, I recommend this anime if you enjoy a fantasy/romance/school anime with a story that is very simple to understand.

It seems to me that some people are taking this anime super seriously. The whole show is supposed to be a joke about how absurd everything is. Yeah, it's about a random guy who's guildmates all happen to be hot girls. Yeah, it makes use of some very common tropes. But the whole anime is so over the top that it's silly and enjoyable. There is an absurd amount of fanservice, but that goes along with the ridiculousness of the rest of the anime. There's many references to MMO culture and that's probably my favorite part of the anime ie. skimpy female armor. It's overallpretty fun to watch if you see it for what it is.

Warning possible Spoilers
Ah the difference between realities and how this can affect our personalities and our way of thinking, what this show does is when you become consumed with virtual reality and forget the real world so luckily this only happens to a very cute girl who ends up having to pull her friends into a really complicated situation.
In a Game called Legendary Age Hideki AKA Rusian proposes to a girl while in game yet tells him she is a dude thus making Hideki think every girl gamer is a complete lie that is until he meets Ako a nooby who he encounters whojust so happens to be in love with him, sadly she can't tell the difference between real life and the game world.

Now I'm a big fan of Romance's and how this played out was actually pretty different for once and it attracts people like myself who are gamer's which adds another nice element to it.

It was really fun seeing Hideki and his friends trying their best to show Ako that the game and the real world are two different things and the things they do to show this don't really help, but the outcome is actually really funny and the interactions between Hideki and Ako can be pretty cute since that they are married in the game she believes they are also married in real life so she always acts lovey dovey with him.

It is also interesting how we get to see the characters perspective in real life and in the game that they play and how they act differently since some of the characters in the group have positions they don't want to be ruined just because they are playing a game, however when it comes to the game it was fun seeing how the group worked together to handle quests or taking a Castle from a rival guild even if the outcome for them isn't always good.


The characters are actually pretty fun and very likeable I didn't find anyone dislikeable or annoying in anyway.

Hideki AKA Rusian is the male MC and is Ako's husband in the game and in real life too in Ako's eyes, he is a pretty straightforward and honest guy and takes the relationship between him and Ako very seriously even if that seriousness doesn't get through to Ako, he does get stressed a lot since explaining things to Ako can be difficult, but he puts up with it like a champ and states her as an important person in his life especially since she is actually a girl in real life and not some dude.

Ako is the female MC and is definitely one of the cutest characters I've seen even if she can't tell the difference between the game and the real world, a lovable Deredere she always clings onto Rusian whenever she can, but she does listen to him and takes his and her friends words into consideration since they are trying to help her although she can be pretty dim, clumsy and forgettable since she would rather spend her days on games rather than going to school, however she can be a little creepy when people start talking about normies which she thinks are scum, but she is pretty much an adorable character.

Akane AKA Schwein is in real life somebody that Hideki avoids, but in the game she is a good friend of his and when they meet in real life it was definitely surprising to them, she is your usual Tsundere and is actually a likeable one as she always gets annoyed when people call her Schwein after she finds out it means Pig, but she can be a good friend as long as it doesn't affect her status in school.

Kyou is the leader of the gamer group and the Student council president at the school, she is actually a very good leading hence her position in both of these places and cares a lot for her gamer friends yet thanks to her rich family she wouldn't hesitate to use money just to unlock better weapons and armour to make her look good.

Yui is the teacher at the others school and becomes their club advisor when they create their gaming club at school, she also turns out to be the person that Rusian proposed to that made him think all girls are dudes, she is actually a soft spoken person yet can be pretty strict especially when the others are being lazy and don't want to do anything productive unless it's to do with games.

Nanako is Akane's best friend and becomes a member of the group later on in the show, at first because of her interactions with Hideki she is disliked by Ako until she said she was just joking around with him then overtime they slowly become friends, she is a very fun girl and usually tries to keep a positive essence going.


Now the artstyle is actually a lot more shiny and sparkly compared to other anime's I've seen which can be said for the female characters eyes that just look very infectious like you can't you eyes off them, I really liked the way the game was designed as it was obviously a shout out to League of Legends, but the characters looked really well designed both in the game and in real life too especially when they are all different classes so they have different armour and weapons to make them stand out, however there are points where they do check out other games like a Call of Duty type game which played more like a Battlefield game.


I thought the comedic aspect was done really well as most of the time it's Ako causing the laughter as her decisions and skills in the game are poor and usually end up with the team getting beaten up by monsters or at least Rusian being beaten up by monsters and the other's would just clear them out and the same can be said in the real world as Ako's confusion with some things make it difficult for the others to explain what it is to her plus the whole interaction with the group is very well done and some of the other characters pull something out of nowhere that just becomes comedic gold.


Now the Romance was actually good as well I liked the relationship between Hideki and Ako albeit a difficult relationship, but it was nice and even adorable seeing their interactions as both of them took the relationship seriously well in their own way and it was nice seeing it develop as Ako slowly started to see the differences between the worlds which built up their relationship and there was some serious moments too like when Hideki and Ako were on the beach sending off fireworks or when Hideki lost all of his gear when his account got hacked it did show that these two can have serious conversations and have it end up not being turned into a joke.


There was some fan service too like the usual beach trip episode and a bath episode too yet I thought these were okay and weren't placed badly in the show, I did enjoy some of the bikini's the girls wore and the bath episode was actually pretty funny as it turned into a chase as Ako was trying to contact Hideki for an answer via video chat and the others didn't want him to see them nude so it wasn't just there for sightseeing there was some funny stuff that came out of it. 


Overall this was a nice different take on a Romance as there have been some fun, weird ones in the past like Midori days and Mysterious Girlfriend X and now this one can be added to that weird yet interesting bunch.

Okay, so the ONLY reason my overall ain't higher is this: 
(there's a slight spoiler you learn within the first episode or two) 
Once the dude realizes his friends have been females playing male characters the whole time,, he simply stops seeing them as their character. This wasn't done gradually at all - it was a complete cop-out. 
This 1) goes against his nonstop claim of "it's not real - it's just a game !!" argument; and 2) it takes away that aspect of there actually being differences from real-life and the game (minus the whole fantasy vs slice of life genre change). 
The restof the series, tho, is quite enjoyable. It's a basic slice of life show, and there's nothing really to take away than feeling happy that these relative loners stopped being scared to meet and were able to live their school life a lot easier. \n\n
By the way, I also watched this whole thing dubbed. The voice choice and acting was rather fluid for most of the cast. The beginning is choppy without context, but it's not that bad. If you're not vehemently opposed to dubs, then do check it out so you can avoid watching the subs rather than the show.

This whole anime is awesome except for a few things, the main character goes back and forth between not liking a girl and liking a girl. The story goes off basis which is okay, the anime starts out as a rpg then a split life of school and rpg games. This anime gave me great enjoyment, some humor never got old in my opinion. 
Spoilers Possibly
The main characters set character is dense at times and makes you feel like head desking. That is pretty much the only thing off about this anime. The ending suits how the anime should be except when he pulls awayfrom the girl which like come on dude make a decision. Some drama is pulled into this anime but overall this anime is worth watching.
